Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I learned how to conduct experiments with precision and accuracy. I became familiar with lab equipment and procedures, as well as reporting the finding of the experiments conducted by myself.
We learned how to use a pH electrode which was neat, but other than that we didn't really learn any new lab skills. I didn't learn any new material either because it was all covered in gen chem.
I learned how to construct lab reports.

I learned how to carry out experiments that have to do with titrations, kinetics, and equilibrium. It was learned how to quantitatively analyze data and conduct science writing in passive voice through many point deductions on lab reports.
None

I learned a lot of general chemistry lab skills, and got very good at doing titrations. I feel like this semester's lab corresponded well with what I was learning in my chemistry class too (Chemistry 167).

I learned a lot of the basic skills that are needed to work in a lab like pipetting and doing titrations. I was able to explore a lot of concepts taught in general chemistry by actually conducting the experiments myself.

I learned how to apply the concepts I learned about in my regular chem lecture in a lab setting. Most of the labs were related to what we were learning in lecture, so it did (somewhat) improve my understanding of those topics.

I definitely learned how to do titrations! I felt much more comfortable in thiss lab course compared to last semester due to the knowledge I've gained. There were actually things I learned in this course that helped me in my Chem 167 course, like ways to think of acid and base interaction.
I learned how to construct an electrolytic cell and titrate with few other lab skills.
Learned how to do labs.
Titrations? How to master devoting 12 hours to lab reports that TF's (esp. Patrick Ginther) like to nitpick?
Indepth understanding of titrations and spectrophotometry. Aided in understanding of companion course CHEM 165.
I learned the importance of precision and accuracy in the laboratory.
Really good course, learned many laboratory techniques.
Different chem lab procedures in relation to kinetics, thermodynamics, and acids and bases
I developed more advanced skills in the lab, such as pipetting volumes accurately, performing alkalinity titrations, purifying a complex, etc.
This course taught me more laboratory skills and how to be organized and report my findings in a lab report.

Considering I took this course alongside Chem 167, I would say I didn't really learn too much in the academic setting of the class. Also, many of the experiments and skills required feel like repeats from first semester of lab.

The course is definitely better than 134L, in terms of grading/lab reports, and I actually enjoyed some of the experiments that were done in the class.
more of the same from last semester. more of an emphasis on reaction mechanisms and actual data collection which was good. more experiments that related to our lecture course as well.

This course is a great opportunity to get hands on experience in the lab. Although the lab reports really suck, being in the lab was quite fun and interesting at times. I have learned a lot about lab technique and methods, knowledge which I will bring with me if I ever work in a research lab. This course has also made me think a lot about sources of error and how to prevent them.
I learned how to titrate.
This course is necessary for basic chemistry lab experience and basic science lab technique.
I learned a lot about chemistry tools that I would use in future labs that hopefully I will participate in.
analytical skills and how to do experiments
NONE
I learned how to perform scientific experiments that corresponded well with what was taught in my Chem 167 course.

Gained more insight on concepts emphasized in Chem 165 lecture, and quizzes in this class definitely helped prepare students for 165 exams. The lab experiments in this semester were definitely more involved and interesting than the experiments in the fall semester.
We did some experiments regarding acids and bases and chemical equilibrium, extraction, and electrochemistry.
General Chemistry Lab 2 was actually quite helpful in understanding the second semester of chemistry class.  This class taught me more advanced skills in the chemistry laboratory.
I learned many useful lab techniques, including recrystallization, titrations, and spectrophotometry.
None
Like last semester, we learned various lab techniques. This time the lab course complemented lecture very well and it helped review/preview topics we would or did cover.

I learned how to be more confident in the lab, and gained an understanding of why certain techniques were used, and what considerations must be made (as well as what approximations must be made in labwork and how intrinsic imprecisions of lab-collected data could be accounted for).
I learned how to do various experiments.
General chemistry lab skills
I learned more about the practical skills of conducting a chemistry experiment and writing lab reports. Specifically, I gained a better understanding of spectrometry and titrations.
This course taught me the fundamental techniques needed in a chemistry laboratory: titrations, spectrophotometry, analysis of data, etc.
Basic Chemistry laboratory skills including writing lab reports and basic experiments.
Lots of lab skills and general chemistry knowledge.
I learned how to write laboratory reports in a professional manner and the basics of chemistry laboratory techniques.
Quantitative and qualitative analysis of lab procedures.
I learned in-depth lab skills that built on the foundations of first semester chem lab. For example, I learned how to do titrations, spectrophotometry, and work with different acids and bases.
I increased my titration and spectroscopy skills in addition to other lab practices.
I learned basic chem lab skills and techniques.
Basic Chem and laboratory skills
Lots of valuable practical skills in lab, in depth knowledge of chemistry concepts, time management skills
I learned about a wide array of experimental methods to quantify and characterize physical properties of chemicals and reactions.
I enjoyed doing the actual lab work in this class. I feel that it provided me experience that I will be able to use when doing actual research in a lab.
More basic chemistry lab skills.
I learned about how to properly handle myself in a lab and all sorts of different experiments that aided my comprehension in my Chemistry lecture.

I was able to become more comfortable using lab equipment and carrying out lab experiments. This class was also helpful in giving me a stronger chemistry foundation. From this course, I learned that I enjoy working in a lab.
Nothing I didn't learn in lecture.

This is the second semester of general chemistry lab and it is pretty straightforward for students who have already taken the course first semester. This semester focuses on titrations heavily so you gain insight on acid/base reactions, buffers, and redox reactions, to name a few. This semester is really about being SUPER knit-picky on your lab reports and making sure you pay attention to details--failure to do so will result in a bad lab report grade.
This course was helpful in reviewing basic lab practices. It was also helpful in reviewing chemistry topics such as equilibrium and the Arrhenius equation.

How to perform basic chemistry laboratory techniques
Chemistry concepts
I learned more information about laboratory techniques and well as more information about chemistry.
Lab skills - titration, precision, lab conduct.
An intense desire for perfection.
I learned more about different topics in chemistry and the existing experiments that reinforce these principles.
I learned how to organize, evaluate and run different chemical experiments.
I learned basic chemistry knowledge.
I learned several chemistry laboratory techniques that enhanced my understanding of material from the lecture course.
I learned lab techniques and methods while also strengthening my knowledge in Chemistry.
In this class you will master techniques such as titrations, using burets, pipettes, and other equipment.
Basic laboratory skills

More advanced practical skills in the lab.
Learned in more depth concepts seen in chem class. Definitely very helpful to go over concepts with Dr. G.
Basic laboratory skills
I developed lab skills relating to second semester chem material.
A lot of basic lab techniques and how to format lab reports

I gained an increased ability to work in the lab, and apply what I was learning in chemistry lecture in a way that both reinforced the information and taught me new aspects of the information through practice.
General chemistry lab skills including pipeting, titrations, etc.
I learned how to use lab equipment and how to do lab work quickly
Further developed skills in titrations, spectrophotometry, acid/base equilibria, indicators, titration curves, etc.

In this course, I became more meticulous in following lab protocols and recording data, and developed my critical thinking about the reactions that occurred and why they did so in the first place. I became more organized and improved my capacity to analyse data and clearly explain the results and what they signified. I learned more about the concepts covered in General Chemistry, such as redox reactions, equilibrium, titrations and electrochemical cells.
I learned more laboratory techniques and improved upon those that we practiced in the first semester.
Similar to last semester, did a lot of work with titrations.
Learnt about valuable basic lab techniques and general chemistry.
You learn the basic chemical lab procedures that help when learning the concepts from the General Chemistry course as well as skills that are helpful when taking other labs.
Titrations mostly.
Lab technique, especially in regards to titrations and photospectrometry.
Chem lab techniques
Basic laboratory skills, especially how to titrate and handle some computer software.
How to do a titration accurately.
Pippetting and stoichiometry

This class was a lot better than CHEM 134L. You get to do more legitimate experiments and gain more skills with basic lab techniques. Some of the stuff from the first semester that students didn't like carries over (the grading scale, the arbitrary grading on lab reports, etc.), but I think it is a decent class.
Laboratory skills

I learned how to use excel to make graphs and how to care a lot about things that don't really matter in actual labs. To be frank, Dr. Ganapathi likes to talk a lot about "precision" and "discipline," but what that really means is anticipating what he wants and putting exactly what he wants in a lab report.
I expanded my knowledge on the lessons taught in the General Chemistry II course, and I also learned about proper laboratory conduct.
I gained a better understanding of how to conduct redox experiments and learned about the underlying mechanisms that drive them.
I learned how skills regarding how to work in a chemistry lab, including the importance of measurements, accuracy, and precision.
I learned how to do a titration, how to separate organic layers, and how to work under time constraints.
I learned how to titrate diprotic acids.
I learned how to do basic chem lab techniques like make a titration curve for example.
nothing

I did not feel that I gained more skills and insight this semester than from last semester. Yes, we did different experiments with different purposes. However, many of the same methods were used (like titrations) and so I did not feel like I learned any new hands on skills in the lab.
This course was very heavy on titration, be it redox or acid-base neutralization. We also did some electrochemistry and thermochemistry experiments.

I gained a plethora of laboratory skills that I came without knowing. Through careful lab formatting skills and performance skills, I feel 100% more prepared to work in a lab outside of the school spectrum.
Chemistry lab techniques, significant figures
Lab techniques and data analysis. as well as helping develop intuition for material covered in chem 165
I learned basic laboratory skills
no skills this course was so unhelpful
I developed basic lab technique skills and built on the foundational skills I learned in Chem 134L.
Very little. Got a review of chemistry concepts from AP chem.
I learned how to conduct basic titrations and learned never to trust your TA's. They are useless.
I learned basic lab procedures and more knowledge as to how to write a lab report.
I improved my lab skills.
Furthered my lab skills. Also I learned how to deal with irrational teachers.
I learned lab conduct and safety, and how to carry out basic lab tasks like measuring, pipetting, weighing, titrations, and graphing on a computer.
I developed the ability to properly utilize lab equipment independently. I also adapted to working in a pressuring environment due to time constraints.
Titrations and spectrophotometry
Titrations, Pipeting
I developed lab skills and a better knowledge of general chemistry.
I learned a lot from this course from titrations to spectrophotometry. I felt much more confident with my skills as a researcher and chemist.

This course built on the foundations set in the first semester. I learned more advanced lab procedures, for example how to separate organic and aqueous solutions. It's also more closely aligned to the general chemistry course, so it is better able to reinforce what we learn in the lecture course.
I developed basic skills in the lab.
general lab skill.
Lab skills

General Chemistry Laboratory II was more difficult than the first, but you learn many new skills. Other than just new experiments, taking a laboratory class teaches you diligence and attention to detail.
I improved in spatial awareness and the ability to function under a high-pressure, time-crunch environment. Also, my lab skills and my knowledge of chemistry grew.

This course taught me a lot about how to follow directions and glean the key information from a mountain of instructions and lessons. There is a lot presented in this course, but it doesn't all come in to play on the lab reports and quizzes. I gained an appreciation for chemistry as a not only a science but a practice in logic and reasoning that rivals some courses I have taken in mathematics. I also learned how to talk about what I did in lab in an educated manner, and I was encouraged to say things that demonstrated I actually understood material and didn't just memorize.
The class provides an overview of simple lab techniques and illustrates basic concepts in general chemistry.

By taking this course, I applied the concepts I learned in chemistry lecture in a laboratory setting. I grew more comfortable in a lab. I also learned more about the capabilities of Excel and my patience for writing lab reports.
Better understanding of physical applications of chemistry and lab techniques.
I learned about several different chemical concepts and how to apply them in lab.
I was apply to somewhat apply what the textbook was teaching me in my general chemistry course.
This course helps in developing technical skills necessary for chemistry lab
The reports and the quizzes are graded very harshly, and the lab reports required a tremendous amount of time to be done.

The grading seemed fairer this semester which I liked. I think it's a bit odd though to expect us to complete the quizzes in 15 minutes - they're really hard sometimes. I also wish the course wasn't set up to stress out its students as much as possible (honestly, it feels like Dr. G does that on purpose).

Strengths: the lab corresponds to what is being taught in Chem Lecture.
Weaknesses: the lab reports are graded based more on small minor errors like significant figures compared to content and data

This class had more weaknesses than strengths. Structurally, the class is organized, but in terms of content, it's all over the place. Labs do not always follow class, so do not expect to encounter relevant and mentally engaging experiments. The quizzes are not difficult, but often students performed poorly because they simply had no idea about what to study. Grading is harsh and nit-picky, and labs consist mostly of titrating and waiting. 

On the positive side, you will encounter an active and supportive network of teachers and TA's who will bend over backwards in order to help you understand something better.

Good way to become familiar with lab techniques in chemistry, especially with the small section designs. However, lab report feedback is not very helpful and just seems like we are doing busywork for the points, without learning much from them.
It's excessively difficultly graded and makes everyone stressed, anxious, and sad

Strengths: The manuals are posted beforehand with sample calculations, and Dr. G always answers any questions you may have. 
Weaknesses: Some TAs were better at explaining that others.
The weekly quizzes are somewhat stressful and the lab reports can be burdensome, but compared to last semester's lab, this one was much better and has improved from the last one.

The course was well-taught - its only weakness was that a lot of points were docked for simple things (such as forgetting to mention 1 thing out of many in the purpose of a lab report) rather than docking points for important things like math and conceptual questions.

This course is a ridiculous amount of work for a half credit. The lab reports are, at the very minimum 8-10 pages, but usually more like 12-15. They will take you hours and hours to write and you will be marked down for the most minute and irrelevant things. Prepare to be extremely frustrated with the grading on reports! Basically all the points I lost had absolutely nothing to do with my understanding of science or lab skills, but my choice of formatting. The quizzes are also pretty difficult but generally fairer than the lab report grading (except the sig figs, which are way overemphasized for no apparent reason). Dr. G is extremely set in his ways, so I would say there is no point in trying to reason with him.

I think a lot of things were improved on this semester over last semester. The ability to drop one lab and one quiz took some pressure off that made me focus less on tiny details and more on seeing the broader picture (which then gave me the insight to correct the tiny details). The strengths are the engaging lecture and the ability to do hands-on learning. The biggest weakness is the time: you can get the experiments done on time, but a few were very stressful, which may lead to lower accuracy.
Strengths of this course include the comprehensive manual, helpful TAs, and Dr. G's prelab lectures. I think this class can be improved if we get a clearer feedback on our lab grades.
The pre-class lectures were helpful in understanding. Sometimes the quizzes seemed a bit unfair.

Strength--Lab reports were (at least) structured

Weaknesses--Way too much work for 1/2 credit. I think its borderline criminal that Yale only gives 1/2 credit for a course that meets 4 hrs per week. Dr. G. will argue that he makes it a point to say on the syllabus that we should not be spending hours of time on lab reports, but in order to meet such specific standards, the lab reports require (at least) 8 hours of additional work, which is simply not fair. Additionally, numerous TF's seem to have this weird superiority complex that they have developed as first year grad students, which I find utterly hilarious--they nitpick lab reports, and often fail to understand the lab manual and procedure. Quizzes are also weirdly worded (but I'm glad Dr. G. listened to us last semester about how much they should be worth). Pre lab lectures don't need to be almost an hour. I'm sorry, but the concepts and lab are not so complex that we need to go on a 10 minute tangent about Gibbs (and how the CRB should be changed to the "Gibbs Chemistry Building"). This length for pre lab lectures wouldn't be an issue if we weren't so crunched for time in all of our experiments--literally every single week.
Strict grading on lab reports. Pre-lab quizzes were stressful but the pre-lab lectures were helpful.

Strength: the labs go complement the lecture course fairly well and do help to understand more of the complex research concepts we can't really go into in lecture.
Weakness: it is designed to make you fail and hate STEM at Yale and stay up late the night before every lab and stress and not get enough sleep. Sure it is only a half credit and doesn't count that much toward GPA but the majority of students taking this course are pre-med and are very high strung when it comes to grades. This class, although it does help to teach concepts, is extremely detrimental to mental health. The lab conduct grading system is also extremely dangerous for students health because if they make a small mistake in lab that could potentially put them in danger, they can only ask for help at the risk of getting a grade deduction. Instead of creating an environment that allows for mistakes and is safe for learning, students are in constant fear and strive to hide all mistakes from TAs and the professor. Deducting points for spilling chemicals should not be allowed because it discourages students from asking for help.
This class had weekly pre-lab quizzes which could be improved. The quizzes tested rote memorization of the lab material, and did not enhance the lab learning experience.
Loved it, feedback was clear.

Grading of lab reports was inconsistent and didn't make sense at times
Lab procedures are well organized and make sense

Strengths of the course included its interactive, hands-on nature and its ability to reinforce concepts that were being taught in General Chemistry 165b. Weaknesses were that the quizzes involved more involved concepts than what was featured in the lab manual/prelab lecture.

This course is a good course for learning, but sometimes it just felt like too much work for the wrong reasons. A lot of time for this class was spent on checking over lab reports and making sure we didn't make small punctuation mistakes, or forget to mention the indicator, or didn't make a sig fig error. Sure these things are important, but sometimes it makes us lose the forest for the trees and only focusing on trying to avoid getting deducted points for no reason at all, preventing us from prioritizing learning the material and gaining more experience using lab equipment.

I believe the course needs more connection to modern chemistry research, for the sake of engagement and interest to the students. Many times I felt like I was just going through the motions of basic chemistry concepts and lab techniques.

the lecture before the lab needs to be shortened by a lot. it would be far more helpful to have a brief lecture in the lab by the TAs describing the actual experiment than to spend 40 minutes going over the theory behind the lab, which is often already known from the lecture course. Dr. G. needs to not spend over an hour each lab day talking.
The grading is a bit tough and varies by which TA grades the lab report/quizzes. It would be more fair if these TAs all graded based on the same standards.

One strength of this course is how organized it is. Dr G. organizes the class very well and ensures that there are no miscommunications throughout the semester. The materials available in the lab is also quite amazing; we have access to so many different and interesting apparatuses to do a lot of interesting labs. 

One weakness of the lab is the length of class itself. It is very difficult to fit a four hour class into a schedule. Maybe if the prelab lecture and actual lab were split up, it would be easier and less overwhelming to fit it into my schedule. 
Another weakness is the discrepancies in grading between TAs for lab reports. If the TAs split up grading so that specific lab reports are graded entirely by a single TA, this would make the grading system more fair.
The lab quizzes were extremely difficult and hard to prepare for, however all experiments were interesting.

This course is great in that Yale has some amazing facilities and resources to give students the introductory lab experience that they need. However, I think this class is designed in some aspects to be a "weed-out" class, and that generates a lot of unnecessary stress and work for students. For example. lab reports are notoriously long, detail-oriented, and tedious. Pre-lab quizzes are also sometimes very difficult, especially if you are taking lab concurrently with the lower level chemistry class (where students haven't learned the material as deeply as those in the other class have).

strengths- I learned so much in one semester, and it better explained concepts form general chemistry.
weaknesses- the class was very difficult and extremely time consuming which was not fun at all

strengths - a lot of feedback

weakness- a lot of work
Super harsh grading for no reason. The lab reports were absolutely not graded for our understanding but for petty formatting or unimportant sig figs.
This course has a straightforward lab manual that clearly defines the expectations of the course. It could be improved by giving better feedback on the lab reports.

Strengths of the course included that the quizzes were largely related to material learned in lecture and emphasized in the lab reports. Additionally, the experiments were interesting most of the time. Weaknesses included that students didn't receive feedback on submitted lab reports for many weeks, which made it difficult to improve information presentation throughout the semester. Also, parts of many labs seemed tedious and unnecessary.

Dr. G was generally willing to answer our questions, and since we had all taken lab with him before it wasn't as tough to figure out the ropes of the course as it may have been last semester. I felt like more than last semester, though, the grading on lab reports was really harsh in this class. It often felt like the graders were just looking for places to take off points instead of being concerned with whether or not we were demonstrating that we understood the material. I felt like the final practical exam was fair, though, based on the experiments that we'd done, but the written test was a little tricky. 

I felt like some of the experiments we did this semester were more interesting than the ones that we did last semester, but I still just felt like the way we were evaluated in this course was more focused on small details in the lab reports instead of ensuring that we learned the material. I think the course could be improved it the grading were changed to reflect that. Also, I think that sometimes the questions in the lab reports could have been changed to be more reflective of what we talked about in the lectures preceding lab.

This course was hard with the intro quizzes but the labs themselves were quite interesting.  The beginning quizzes each day of lab were incredibly hard and the calculations were hard to follow without instruction being given before taking the quiz.

The labs themselves were very interesting, and I learned a lot of lab techniques. The grading of the lab reports seemed inconsistent and very specific, with most points taken off for formatting errors.
quizzes were pointlessly difficult

I liked this semester's grading breakdown much better than last semester's. Like last semester, Dr. G was generally good at explaining the topic related to our experiment that day. Some of the labs were definitely a slog and you'd dread them. There were also vast disparities in terms of TF helpfulness as well as quiz feedback.
The four-hour lab sessions can be intense, but also enjoyable if you prepare for the experiments well.
The experiments are not relevant to modern chemistry research, although they do follow coursework fairly well. The grading is incredibly picky.
Too much work for half a credit. The quizzes take way too much studying to do well on for a class that is only half a credit.
better feedback on lab reports needed and generally clearer instructions

The strengths of the course are that you get experience working in a chemistry lab and conducting experiments. Some of the weaknesses are that the class is very time-consuming. The lab reports take a very long time to complete and the grading is very strict and will take off points for small details.
Not an enjoyable course; grading makes no sense
This course is very well organized, and all the procedures are very clearly outlined.
Thought it was pretty good

The pre-lab lectures helped a lot with learning and reinforcing the concepts that would show up in the laboratory as well as in my CHEM 167 class. However, the lab reports usually involved a lot of tedious work. I understand that one of the class's purposes is to teach students how to write a formal lab report, but I feel that taking off points for small errors, such as lacking tick marks on graphs, is a bit excessive and will drive a lot of students away from the field of chemistry. The lab reports usually took hours to complete outside of the four-hour lab, but since the course was only worth 0.5 credits, it seemed like a lot of our hard work was for nothing. The course should be based more on our knowledge of chemistry rather than our ability to use Excel. Furthermore, points would sometimes be taken off on lab reports without any further explanations than an abbreviation for what type of error it was (for example, SF for sig figs), and because the scores wouldn't be posted on Canvas until several weeks later, it was hard to improve on the later lab reports without knowing what to improve on.

This course demanded a lot of time for both lab reports and labs. It was sometimes very hard because the quizzes were also challenging, but overall, I would say it did well in helping students thoroughly learn the concepts taught in Gen Chem class. Not much is needed to improve the quality of the class.

I know this won't change anything, but to be honest, this is more work heavy than simply half a credit. I took a 1.5 credit course this semester that only met 10 minutes more each week, and homework wise still felt comparable to Chem Lab. While there are days in which we do not use the full lab time, enough of it is used to still feel as though it is more than half a credit once the hours per one lab report and quizzes are factored in. We learn lab practices and what not just fine, but psychologically, it's annoying when you're told all this work is half a credit. I don't even care much that it is half aside from the knowledge that the workload itself is not reflective of that, and even an acknowledgement that this course is work wise more than half credit while keeping the system the same would make me feel better. Additionally our quizzes were often handed back with plenty of acknowledgement of correct vs incorrect with little to no remarks on why.

I thought some labs were interesting and the lab procedures were very organized. I learned how to do certain procedures and write lab reports with utmost attention to detail. I often found grading discrepancies in lab reports, which made it a little difficult to learn from and realize how to improve.
The grading was unnecessarily picky (I. E. Losing large quantities of points for minuscule details rather than losing points for Chemisty concept understanding)

The grading was much better this semester, and I liked that we got to drop our lowest quiz and lab report grade. I also thought the workload was reasonable, although it did seem sometimes overwhelming to have a lab report every week (as long as I started early, I was fine).

This course is very interactive, engaging, and instructive. Every pre-lab lecture was effectively organized, and the lab experiments were perfectly married to the concepts that the professor was aiming to teach that day. Lab protocols were mostly intuitive, and when they weren't, the lab TAs did a good job providing help and explained the rationale behind their answers. However, the follow-up lab reports, while important, felt overly tedious, and I wondered if lab reports could a serve a purpose beyond collecting, displaying and analyzing data--such as ask questions in the middle about what it would if you data looked like X, or challenge you to think why the protocol was designed the way it was.

This class did provide the opportunity to get some hands-on experience doing certain lab techniques. However, the lab reports required way too much work than what I believe should be needed for a 0.5 credit course.
This course was very fair.

The experiments and lab reports are well structured but I think they are often longer than they need to be. Sometimes the grading seems kinda weird where on a report you will just lose points for the same significant figures error like 3 times in row.

I think that although this course does teach a lot about Chemistry it is incredibly stressful for students so much so that they care more about the grades they receive instead of actually learning the material. This could be improved by eliminating quizzes and having the TFs do a rundown on what the experiment will be once in the lab instead of having a lecture that explains what the experiment will be. I think this would make students much more engaged and would lessen the pressure of the course.
Less emphasis on memorization on pre-lab quizzes. I wish lab reports were graded with more of an emphasis on learning the science behind the experiments rather than formatting graphs and sigfigs

I enjoyed that this class aligned well with the topics covered in my General Chemistry 165 course. Taking both courses at the same time really helped me in learning and understanding the concepts. However, this course involved a lot of time (time in the lab and time doing lab reports) even though it was only worth half a credit. I learned a lot in this class and it was interesting, but I ended up being in lab for 4 hours a week and spending about 10 hours a week doing lab reports. I did like that the final lab practical was done during the last week of classes rather than during reading period or final exams period.

This course just tries to make you compete with the other poor suckers taking it by making a reverse curve and then giving not enough clear details in general. Honestly, piazza would help this course a lot.

Strength: Hands down my TA Ya-na saved me this semester. She really cared about us and took the time to make sure all our questions on lab reports were thoroughly answered. She was so kind and considerate that the course was easily pleasant thanks to here. 

Weaknesses: I think the grading on the lab reports has gotten immensely better compared to last year's. I have heard so many horror stories of students who lost points just for not being as neat on their laboratory notes. This did not happen this semester, and it is mainly I think because Dr. G did not grade any labs. Instead, the TA's graded all of our labs.  Last semester we were given grades of either 60, 55,45, 30 (or something of this scale) and it was super frustrating because it always felt like it was impossible to get a 60. I think overall I enjoyed this semester of chemistry lab a lot and I do not think it was difficult so long as you put in the work and come prepared.

The course was good but the grading was very variable depending on who graded it. more consistency would be great. The written portion of the final exam was also, in my opinion, unreasonable as it required the memorization of obscure details from lab reports despite us being told to study the procedures.

Strengths:
Good reinforcement of chem topics
Learn how to do a lot of chem lab techniques

Weaknesses:
Way too much packed into the semester
Grading can be unreasonable
Too much emphasis on accuracy (too many points given to)
Far too much emphasis is placed on absolute precision to the point of missing out on some of the key things that should be learned in an introductory lab course.
The course is very well organized but some evaluations did not effectively test essential knowledge.

This course is a lot of work for a half credit. I spent just as much if not more time in this class than I did in my full credit classes.
This course turns the excitement I once had for Chemistry into a chore, something that must be done once a week.

One of the main strengths is the organization of the course and the ability of Dr. G to answer questions we might have about the material. 
A main weakness is the absolute randomness of the grading for the lab reports; throughout the semester, they were graded inconsitently and we werent told of some of the aspects of our lab reports for which points were taken off until after the fact.
The grading isn't fair and the labs are too long.
inconsistent grading with little to no explanation.
Sometimes the lab reports can be extremely long and tedious. However, they teach you how to be meticulous with your own work.
Very organized class structure.
Course is organized

Very long: 4 hours seems like too much for a class worth half a credit. Also, the lab reports take too much time to do, and are corrected very severely.

The experiments are interesting and help to understand concepts that we go over very broadly/theoretically in chem class.
Its very well organized but sometimes what is wanted on the lab reports is unclear.

General Chemistry Lab is a difficult course, particularly in terms of workload. I find it incredible that I put in far more time into this half credit course than my full credit chemistry lecture course. One improvement would be making this half credit course a full credit course, as would be fitting given the class hours and workload. I feel like I did learn valuable lessons in time management and being meticulous with my work, but I certainly spent far more time on this course than is called for by a half credit course.
I wish the lab reports were not nearly as long.
Strengths are it is well organized. Weaknesses are it is too focused on formatting
I think that this course is very well organized and thought out! I really enjoyed taking part in the lectures and labs! I honestly don't know if there is anything to be improved upon!

This course is extremely nit picky in its grading, with points being taken off for minuscule things like formatting. The grading is not consistent among TAs. The lab reports are also extremely long, and due to the formatting requirements, they take much more time to do than they should. This class causes unnecessary stress for many students and detracts them from taking future lab classes.
It was too much work for a 0.5 credit course. Grading was also pretty tough for no reason sometimes

This course is useful in providing a strong foundation in chemistry laboratory techniques. However, the grading of the course is too strict and arbitrary at times, so more time is spent trying to meet every specific lab report requirement than learning proper lab technique.

Given that this is a lab course, and even though understanding of the experiment and the necessary calculations is important, quizzes are sometimes challenging (and especially completing them in 15 minutes). However, I do think it helps to have them, but having choices in which questions to answer would help demonstrate the student's knowledge of the topic perhaps better than the quizzes can. I also think that students are spoon-fed the experiments too much, and although it would be difficult for students to come up with these protocols on their own, it would be good to make students come up with part of this protocol to make them more autonomous.

This course is strong in practicing and reinforcing lab techniques, and working with a partner allows more confidence in learning them. However, the quizzes are unnecessarily long and difficult, and cause a lot of stress when preparing for lab days.

Prelab lectures were very helpful but the weekly quizzes did not aid my learning at all or help me with the actual lab after it. The lab reports are graded heavily based on format rather than content and grading is often inconsistent.
Well organized, well structured course. Perhaps the workload could be decreased somewhat. Some of the lab reports were exceptionally long.

Strength: You learn the basics of lab safety and chemical reactions which is helpful to see the course material from CHEM161/165 come to fruition in front of you. 

Weakness: The prelab lectures are sometimes too involved--students who come prepared to class just need questions answered which could save on time.
Very difficult to do well on quizzes and lab reports.

Strengths: learned the desired concepts very effectively and helped my gain confidence in many skills.

Weaknesses: overall very stressful - quizzes were sometimes unnecessary and lab reports way too long.
Final written exam was hard to prepare for. More guidance with this would be helpful.
It is the workload of a full credit

It is really cool to get to work in the lab and do experiments. I think in that sense it is a good course. I think it isn't as great of a course in terms of how it is run  the quizzes, the lab reports, the pre-lab lectures. I think the grading should be less arbitrary (e.g. losing fewer points for formatting) but I did like the class.
It's a long time for one class and I felt the quizzes were unnecessary.

The strength of this course is how it complements what is learned in general chemistry lecture and design of the lab procedures. The weakness is basically every other aspect of the course. The grading is inconsistent, often with insufficient feedback or reasoning. The grading system itself is oftentimes very arbitrary and not adequately communicated. I fundamentally disagree with the things that are emphasized in labs and lab reports (as in the meticulous detail concerning graphs, accuracy of data, etc.). I also feel that pre-lab quizzes do little to aid my understanding of the lab or understand the calculations. Rather, they are just exercises in brute memorization of lab calculations. These concerns were raised to Dr. Ganapathi at the end of the 1st semester. In his 1st lecture of the 2nd semester, he said he received this feedback (especially that regarding lab quizzes) and would make no changes because he disagreed with us.

I think this class could be infinitely improved in three ways: 1) by standardizing a grading system where individual aspects of the lab report are worth points and you gain points rather than lose them for mistakes, 2) by focusing on self-reflection and procedural analysis in lab reports, and 3) by eliminating or fundamentally changing the quiz system.

1) The grading system as it stands now is arbitrary, poorly designed, and poorly communicated. Although many of the mistakes that will lose students points are detailed in the syllabus, those mistakes oftentimes are arbitrarily ruled on. Sometimes, I'll lose 1/2 a point for a mistake in the purpose section of a lab report if the mistake is deemed minor. Sometimes, I'll lose a full point if it's deemed major. That is outlined in the syllabus. What isn't outlined is losing 2 points on a mistake deemed "super major." At multiple points this semester and last semester, I'd lose arbitrary amounts points for mistakes that are outlined in the syllabus. Sometimes, I'd lose as many as 4-5 points out of a 50 point lab report for making the same mistake (not adding tick marks to my graph axes) multiple times, as if I was supposed to realize I was making the mistake while I was doing the lab report. And all the while, I was losing points for mistakes that aren't outlined in the syllabus as well (like accuracy of data). To fix this, Dr. Ganapathi should apportion points to individual parts of the lab reports proportional to their overall weight in the lab report. So, if there are 7 major calculations and graphs in a lab report, each would be worth five points with the purpose, data sheets, and general formatting of the lab report being worth 5 points each. And the scale would shift depending on how many calculations and graphs there are. That way, you can't lose more points than a section is worth (which has happened on a few occassions for me). Adequately communicating to students what will be graded and how harshly is also essential. Finally, graders must stick to the grading system.

2) Very rarely does a lab report ask me to analyze procedure and look for potential errors in procedural design. Troubleshooting and looking for where variation might be introduced into data is what science is about, not formatting graphs to one person's liking. More time and points should be allocated to this pursuit rather than to how things should be formatted.

3) The quiz system is terrible as it stands. It should either be eliminated (since it causes an undue amount of stress for a 0.5 credit course) or revamped so it actually tests familiarity with concept and procedure rather than brute calculations. Asking students to read through the protocol and note 2-3 points where variation could be introduced would be much more useful than the current set-up.

I doubt any of this feedback will be incorporated. Dr. Ganapathi has demonstrated an unwillingness to incorporate constructive feedback. I hope this will help to change that or at least bring attention to the problem.

The weekly quizzes do not seem to be an effective method of learning for a lot of students, especially with the lab and lecture sections scheduled so closely. This could be improved by allowing students to take the quizzes online.
The experiments in the lab were very interesting and fun to conduct. The quizzes were incredibly difficult at times and we weren't given any much guidance on how to prepare for them.
The quiz grading was off- some TAs graded much nicer than others, which was not fair at times.

This course covers difficult concepts, that we are then tested on during weekly quizzes, but the concepts are never adequately taught. We are expected to understand the concepts via a 5 minute lecture and looking over some examples. I didnt learn how to preform the calculations on the quizzes; I simply memorized them. But, I do feel confident in my laboratory abilities and would feel comfortable in the lab.
This class was extremely stressful due to how strict the lab reports were graded.

This course has a few weaknesses. One is the structure of the quizzes. I think it's slightly unreasonable to have a lecture on a subject and then immediately take a quiz. Additionally, and more importantly, the lab reports should not be focused on such tedious things and take 12+ hours. That doesn't add any educational value for us, and they are graded too stringently.

I felt it was graded much too harshly. I also believe that for the excessive amount of time this course took, it should be worth more than .5 credits. I poured hours and hours into the lab reports and also 4 hours a week in the lab. It was much more work than any of my other classes and yet was only worth .5 credits.

I am now very comfortable using titration as a method for determining the concentration of analyte, so that is a strength. I would like to see perhaps more variety so students can get more practice using other forms of analytical chemical techniques.

This course prepares you to perform in a lab with simple techniques. It is a great intro course to simply introduce you to the most important skills you would need to know. In terms of its weaknesses, this class often preoccupied the majority of my time with the incredibly dense lab reports. The lack of a makeup week was unfair; as it forced people who got sick to still lug themselves to lab in order to avoid a dropped score.
Organized well, but definitely should be worth more than 0.5 credits
Its was fair and whatv I feel the class should be

I thought the quizzes were almost impossible to do well on and I thought doing calculations before we did the lab report made them very difficult. The final written exam was also basically impossible unless you had the memorization skills of a god. Also, the lab reports were often times very harshly graded, and we wouldnt get our grade back until weeks later so we were not able to fix any of the same mistakes we made.
i think that the quizzes were pointless and did not help us retain any information
The course coincides well with General Chemistry 165 and offers a hands on learning experience for the lecture.

Strengths: good REVIEW of AP chem concepts
Weaknesses: unreasonably high workload for the tiny amount of actual learning that occurred. Almost all of the time spent was not learning interesting relevant material but was spent making lab reports fit an exact format. In other words, time was wasted trying to format reports on excel rather than actually learning anything new. Hard courses are fine, but hard courses where you don't learn anything and just do busy work are disappointing.
Have more competent Teaching Fellows.

I just didn't really enjoy going to class. I dreaded it most of the time. Writing the reports never felt like I had to think, but rather like I needed to do what Dr. G wanted. I was more worried about hitting "return" the right number of times than I was about knowing the calculations and understanding the concepts of the course.
Very difficult grading. The class was structured well but the pre-lab quizzes were too hard and difficult to prepare for. Also, the lab reports were extremely tedious and time consuming.
Get rid of Dr. G.

The quizzes before the lab experiment felt unnecessarily hard to me. No matter how much I studied calculations in the lab manual, I didn't understand how to do many of the questions on the quizzes. The quiz grades bring my entire class grade down when I feel like the lab reports should count much more.

The course's lab manuals offer very clear instruction, reflecting the material discussed during the pre-lab lecture. However, the somewhat inconsistent grading between TAs (which at times can be very nitpicky and at other times can be very forgiving) could be improved.
The professor is the weakness!

I've said this before but I think the fact that the final exam grade is determined by percent accuracy is not really fair (especially when the accuracy is reliant on sensors that may be faulty). I also think the lab reports are not always designed in a way that helps me actually understand the material (for example, a large part of one of the lab reports was just marking things on graphs, which felt silly to me because I understood the concepts but making so many little lines on excel was the time consuming part).

The main strengths were Dr.G's pre-lab lectures. I thought they were very direct, clear and helpful in conducting the experiment as well as writing up the lab report. However, one tiny weakness of this course was the points they would take off for the purpose of the lab reports. A lot of the time I thought the grading of this was inconsistent and unfair.

The ability to drop your lowest quiz and lab score is very useful, especially because some of the quizzes can be quite tricky. However I think the final lab and exam should be worth more than what they currently are, so that you can have a chance to improve your grade at the end of the year with a good score. 
If the course has one weakness, it's that the lab reports need to be very detailed, and formatted in a specific way. If you do it wrong, or miss some things, it can really hurt your grade for that lab.
This course prepares students well for basic laboratory chemistry. Beyond that, I think there's a tremendous amount of busywork. The workload for this course makes it feel like a full credit.

Lab reports are very difficult and time consuming and grading is ridiculous, This course should be worth more because it is so much time. Lab experience completely depends on whether you have a good or bad TA.

Strengths: basic skills 
Weaknesses: many skills are irrelevant to real labs

I think this course's strengths is the bonding of students. Since it is rigorous, students bond over lab days and lab reports. It's weaknesses is the lack of fun material. The course is very dry. It would be better if the labs were more exciting.

Strengths- Dr. G is a great lecturer and I got better understanding of chemistry concepts from this course than I did in actual 165b lecture.

Weaknesses- the Lab Reports can be way too difficult sometimes and are graded harshly by some TA's and much more generously by others.

The class helpfully covers topics that you need to understand before progressing further in biology or chemistry. At times, it's more focused on concerns such as percent error and cleanliness of glassware than on grasping more basic concepts like the reactions that are occurring in the exercises, but I understand why those topics are still included in the curriculum. I think Dr. Ganapathi has too much responsibility for too many aspects of the class. It would probably be more enjoyable if more of the responsibility was delegated to TAs and he was free to be concerned about teaching the concepts -- this would allow him to focus more on the really important aspects of the material while leaving the housekeeping aspects of the course up to others. He is a good lecturer and gives clear explanations, in addition to being helpful to students, but the class forces him to be spread too thinly.

One strength of the course is its relative compatibility with CHEM 165. It really helped to learn the concepts in lecture and then go to lab to experiment on these concepts, so I would know what to vaguely expect during the experiment. A weakness of the course was the variability of the lab report grading. Since a different teaching fellow would grade the lab reports each week, I could never expect what would be counted against. I would highly recommend if the lab report grading was as consistent as the quiz grading.
Very in-depth material and lab handouts; however, the difficulty of the lab quizzes caused a lot of unnecessary stress and were graded in frustratingly picky ways.

Strengths: It helped me learn a good bit of chemistry.
Weaknesses: The quizzes could be a little annoying because they would often include questions not really covered in the prelab lecture.

The quizzes were the toughest part of the class for me. I understand the importance of knowing what's going to be on the lab, but I feel that testing us on calculations and in-depth knowledge of lab material should be done after we have fully completed the lab.
The TA's were not very helpful when they provided feedback on our lab reports. I was deducted different amounts of points for similar mistakes, so there was not always consistency.
The quizzes of this course were very difficult and required a  lot of prep beforehand.
Take it only if you have to take it.
Don't take it if you don't have to. It's on science hill, it's four hours long, the lab reports are annoying....just don't.
Take it only if you need to

Everyone takes this class in order to fulfill a prerequisite. Better put: no sane person takes this class unless it is necessary. Beware harsh grading, disorganized content, poor instructions, long hours, and a large workload.

This class is very formulaic. You attend pre-lab lecture, you take a quiz, attend lab, and complete a lab report. This seems fair up front, but it is not. You will be performing egregious amounts of work for half a credit. Grading is very strict, and the material does not always correlate with class. Be prepared to lose 15/50 points because your graph was too small, or receive 0/50 points because you wrote something in pencil, not pen. The labs themselves are easy to complete, but you will still spend three to four hours doing repetitive tasks. Heuristic learning has its benefits, but a worker on the assembly line doesn't gain vast knowledge about how their product functions. And that is what you are: a worker on the assembly line. You will be titrating, measuring, measuring again, and waiting. Rinse and repeat. 

Here is some math. To be generous, let's say every week you spend from 2:00 to 5:00 in the lab. In reality, this is more likely to be 1:45 to 5:00. On average, you are spending 3 hours in the lab. There were ten labs this semester. Simple multiplication: 30+ hours a semester in the lab. Initially this seems innocuous, even like a small amount. But then break it down. Those are 30+ hours of your life that you will stand in a dry room, stirring, pouring, and waiting, utterly unstimulated. Now take into account the lab reports. To be very generous, let's say that these are about 10 pages long. Google tells me it takes approximately 45 minutes to write a page. So then 450 minutes per lab report, 4500 minutes for the semester, that's 75 hours. Now we're looking at 105+ hours for the semester. Adding on pre-lab lecture, this comes out to about 115+ hours, excluding any personal time you wish to take to study. This is a significant time commitment for a 1/2 credit. I leave it up to your discretion whether you believe that this is worth it. 

I mentioned outside studying. There will be times when you need to learn material outside of lab in order to perform well on the quiz. For the final, you will be expected to memorize random details from your labs throughout the semester and regurgitate them. By random details, I mean mole ratios and the formulas of obscure molecules that you then need to balance. 

To be perfectly honest, it's not "that bad." The class is perfectly doable. You might even find solace in the camaraderie between classmates, or fun in trading jokes with your TAs or Dr. G. However, Yale is expensive. If you were to take five classes a semester each semester (as of 2018, tuition is $53,430 excluding room and board), then each class you take will coast about $1335.75. That same money could get you a new laptop, phone, 2 tickets to a 3-day astronaut simulation, 267 five-dollar coffees, etc. My point is that we are at an incredible, life-changing institution that affords us boundless opportunities everyday, so why spend so much time doing something that you do not find interesting or fulfilling? One thousand dollars can get you a lot. Don't waste it on this class.
Not necessarily a class you'd take just for the fun of it, but also a fairly enjoyable class for the pre-meds and majors who have to take it for requirements. It is what you make of it.
If you have to take it then fine, but otherwise no. It's a huge time drain and is unpleasant

This course is generally required, so you have to take it. It's not as horrible as people sometimes say--it's definitely a struggle and takes a lot of time to prepare for the experiments and lab reports. However, if you put in the time and effort, you will find help.
Yes, if you are in STEM or pre-med.

If you have the choice not to take it, do so. The time it takes to complete the weekly lab report (if you want to do a good job) plus the fact that labs usually fill the full four hours is disproportionate relative to the fact that it's a 0.5 credit course.

I would not recommend this course to any human being. Take it if you have to, but if it's not absolutely necessary, do not take it. There is no point. You will not enjoy it, it will eat up your time, complicate your schedule, drive you a little bit crazy.... maybe if you wanted to test your academic pain tolerance or ability to stay sane under ridiculous circumstances?

Take it if you're planning to do STEM, because you will need it, and it's also a great way to figure out early whether or not you actually want to work in a lab. They definitely try to make the experiments fun, with lots of cool colors.
I would recommend this course to a student who is taking introductory chemistry. While the lab reports do take long to complete, I believe that they are manageable and not very challenging.
Yes, who wants an introduction to gen chem lab.

Let's not fool anyone--no one "recommends" CHEM 136L. This course shortchanges students, requiring 12 hrs/week for 1/2 measly credit. Do I think it's a travesty that classes like "Jews in the Muslim Lands" are worth double this class? Yup. Will anything be done in the near future? I hope so.
Do it if you need to. Otherwise, there's probably better ways to learn the same things.
You're only taking it because you have to take it. Get a group of friends together so you can fight through it together.
I would not recommend this course unless it is required for your major
Yes, especially if someone is interested in learning more chemistry.

I would recommend this course to another student if he/she/they needed it for requirements, or if the person wanted to develop more advanced skills and knowledge in general chemistry in a lab setting. I would recommend it to students taking General Chemistry 165b as the course reinforces concepts.
I would recommend this course to anyone who wants to study in the sciences because it really does prepare you for lab work and trains you to think like a scientist.
If you took 134L, no. But many students need this as a requirement.
If you like experiments this isn't a bad class. the pre lab lectures are really long and the lab reports can take many many hours but the actual labs aren't too bad.

Yes. Although the course is a pretty challenging and arduous, I did develop my lab skills throughout the semester-- which is the main point of the class. Definitely a class any person interested in pursuing science should take.

I would only recommend this course to students truly interested in Chemistry (i.e. this is a course that is a pre-req or requirement of your major, not just taking it for fun). It is a great course and can be very interesting at times, but the amount of time you'll put into the course is not worth it for the 1/2 credit you'll receive if you really don't need the credit.
No.
Again, this is a required lab for many majors and fields so I would and it's not a bad class, just a tough one.
Yes- I think basic chemistry lab skills are important for all students interested in STEM. However, I believe that this lab course could be designed to bolster learning with less stress.
You have to take lab for most stem majors, but if you dont have to dont take the class.
you only take this because you have to
Not at all.

I would recommend this course to a student that needed it to fulfill a requirement, but I would not recommend this course for someone who wanted to get a deep understanding of what exactly is happening in the scientific experiments because I feel as though some of the labs were not very clear in the meaning of the labs.

If you need to take a general chemistry lab course, the spring semester is definitely better than the fall semester. However, parts of lab can still be frustrating at times if you are not passionate about the subject.

Not unless you need it. I know that sometimes it's difficult to know if you'll need a lab course, especially if you're undecided about your major, but I don't think that you should worry about taking this course if you may not need it (I took it as a precaution, and now I know I'm not going to major in a natural science so I didn't need to take it at all).

Yes, I would recommend this class to another student.  I would definitely recommend if the student was taking second semester of the class because this lab helped in understanding many of the concepts being explained during the lecture course.
I would. It's a good course for learning general chemistry lab techniques.
No
I didn't really enjoy this course, and you probably just have to take this.
Yes, if you would like to gain basic lab technique skills and help augment your understanding of general chemistry concepts.
Only if they have to complete it for a major. It is not fun nor useful in learning chemistry, and is a lot of work for a half credit.
Not unless required
Only take if you have to.

If you are taking this course, most likely you're premed/ need it as a prerequisite for your major. It's definitely not a course people take for fun to satisfy the science distributional requirement, but I would recommend it to anyone who has to take it.
don't take this class unless you have to

No, do not take this course unless it is a requirement. While the course is straightforward and expectations are clear, it is very difficult, laborious, and frustrating. It was not an enjoyable course, but as a requirement you just have to get through it.
Yes.
Only take this course if need be. The amount of time put into the course compared to the knowledge received from it is not very worth it.
Lots of unnecessary busy work, big time commitment, did not help me master the material.

I would recommend this course if you want to better understand the concepts taught in Gen Chem class. You get hands-on practice doing a lot of techniques and concepts taught in second semester General chemistry.
I mean if you have to take it do so. If not, find another class you will probably enjoy more.
c
I would recommend this course if it is a pre-requisite for a major/pre-professional track
This is good for learning basic lab skills.
Don't take this course as an elective, but if it's required for your major, you'll be fine as long as you stay organized and ask questions

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. I think this course is self-contained, meaning that the appropriate techniques can be picked up in class and requires no prior experiences and/or courses in chemistry. I think this class is enjoyable, and it makes many abstract chemistry concepts very tangible. I do feel like the lab sessions are rigid, and while the protocols certainly are wonderfully helpful, I wonder if it might be equally beneficial to our education if we were allowed to design parts of the experiments ourselves. That way, we would have think more critically about why we do certain steps and learn how to interpret unusual data.
Take this class only if you need it. If you just need a science credit, don't do it.
Really only take it if you have to, but its not as bad as everyone makes it out to be.
If you need to take, I enjoyed second semester much more than first semester, so you should continue with it.
I strongly recommend you don't take this course unless you have to. It is time-consuming, difficult, and very stressful.

Avoid if at all possible. Too much emphasis on memorizing chemical formulas on the prelab quizzes, lab reports graded unnecessarily harshly (I got multiple points taken off because the tick marks on my graphs only went half way through the axis instead of crossing all the way). I feel like I like the only skill I really learned was how to google my formatting questions about excel.

I think the organization of this class and the grading structure was much better than last semester (Gen Chem Lab 134). Dr. G is a good lecturer and it is nice that his course aligns well with the Gen Chem lecture course. In this way, I was able to better learn and understand the concepts covered in both courses. This lab is a pretty big time commitment for only half a credit (4 hours a week in lab and up to 10 hours a week completing lab reports) and is a requirement for the pre-med track. The course isn't the greatest, but I did learn a lot and so would recommend it for this reason.
Absolutely not. Not worth the time and effort you put into it.

Yes, but only if this class is required for you. I do not think that you should take this course unless you can really afford to put forth a credit's worth of work only to get 0.5 credits for the class. This class is not easy, but if you are dedicated and keep up, it is not hard to do well.
I think this is a fine course to take but I have heard that it is not especially representative of lab courses at Yale.
No, it's more difficult than it's worth.
You learn a lot of lab techniques, but the workload is unreasonable for a half credit class. Don't take unless you have to.
No, unless you have to take it
Only if it is a required course.
Only if it is required.

I think because the class is not exactly attached to a class, like one of the general chemistry courses, it just feels like you're learning something random every week that you might never use again. So it is hard to really see it as necessary.
Its a rigorous, grueling but thorough course. You will learn.
Unless you are majoring in one of the natural sciences or are a premed, I do not recommend taking this class.
One should certainly take this course if necessary for requirements they might have. Otherwise, it does take a lot of time and effort to do well.
Only take it if you have to.
This class is definitely a great experience. Many people I know were not very enthusiastic about going to lab, but I enjoyed it as I had a great TA and close friends in my group.
Yes, since it is very useful for further studies.
yes, Dr. G is very structured and patient.

I would not recommend this class unless it is a pre-requisite for the student's major.
Indeed, it takes up a lot of time, both in class and to do the lab reports, which does not seem worth it for half a credit.
Furthermore, the weekly quizzes tend to be stressful.
It gives you a good understanding of how to use basic laboratory equipment and follows along with chem 165 very well
Yes. It is a very interesting a helpful course.
I would recommend this course only is a necessary prerequisite.
I would recommend this course to any student who wants to learn proficiency in a lab environment, and reinforce chemistry knowledge through application.
I would only recommend this class to someone if they absolutely had to take it as a requirement.
For a lot of people, it is required. I would not recommend it if you are looking to have fun

This is probably not a course that I would recommend a student take for fun or to stimulate their "intellectual curiosity". It is essentially a requirement to reach upper-level chemistry lab courses, and is a required course for all of the biology, chemistry, and pre-med students.

Most of the students taking this class take it as a prerequirement, either for their major or for the pre-med track. I would not recommend this class to a student interested in the class just for a science credit, but if someone is interested in learning the basics of chemistry lab experiments and is willing to put in the time and effort for this class, then it might be a good option for them.
Well its required basically, but its a learning experience, so sure.

I would recommend this course to another student for the sole reason that it may be necessary for them to take the class for their requirement, but would make them aware of the difficulty and workload beforehand.
Yes. Many valuable skills and a lot of valuable knowledge to be gained.

This class is necessary for many science majors, so I would suggest completing this course as early as possible. It's certainly not the most exciting lab, but it's important to have the fundamental skills before taking other labs.
Only if you have to as a requirement for a major.
I would only recommend this course if you had to take it for a prerequisite.
Not unless you have to take for premed.
Not if it is not required, it is very antiquated

I would say take it if you have to, or if you are really interested in chemistry lab. You get to do cool experiments and learn a decent amount, but it may not be worth the hassle for half a credit if you don't have a reason to take it.
It's required.

I would definitely not recommend this course to another student, but my recommendation doesn't matter since many people are required by their major to take this course. That is why it is so important to make this course better. As it stands now, the course is poorly designed (focusing on lab report formatting and Dr. Ganapathi's preferences rather than procedural analysis), is poorly graded (the grading system is often arbitrary and poorly communicated to students), and has assessments (pre-lab quizzes) that do little to contribute to learning in the class. This class is a constant headache, and no one should take this course as it stands unless they absolutely have to. I hope the Chemistry Department will consider making fundamental changes to the course so that students actually benefit from it.

I would recommend this course if it is a requirement as a part of a pre-med track or other pathway. Otherwise, I would advise against it. With the B+ grading scale, it can be difficult to get a better grade.
Absolutely not, unless you HAVE to take it (i.e. premed prereqs).
I would recommend it for someone who needs to take a chemistry lab.
Yes, but I particularly enjoyed the structure of Chemistry Lab from fall term better than spring term.
No, especially for non-STEM students.
No. I would only recommend this course to those who HAVE to take it for degree requirements or premed. Its a lot of work and very little learning.
Please dont take this class unless you HAVE to.
Not really. You probably have to take it for a major or premed requirement, but this class causes undue stress and time. The grading is maddeningly unfair, and the structure is designed poorly.
not unless you need it
Honestly, just do your best. I worked very hard and probably did not necessarily get a great grade in the end. I would not recommend taking this course unless you are premed.
As with first semester gen chem lab, do not take this unless you need to. There are more interesting and fun labs out there.

I would only recommend this course if the student is absolutely sure they are interested in a future STEM career. This class isn't worth it if the student is merely curious, as it takes up way too much time out of a schedule for half a credit.
NO! Only take this course if you must to fulfill a requirement.
If you must take general chemistry lab, this is your only choice
Only if major or pre med requirement
Dont take this unless you HAVE to for your major. Or if you are pre-med :(
i think that i would not recommend it because for a half credit, it was the workload of like 1 credit
I wouldn't recommend it to students who don't need it for their major because of the time commitment that the lab reports take.
Absolutely not. Unless you must take it for major requirements, this course is neither interesting nor engaging. You will spend far too much time on it for the amount you will actually learn.
Don't take this unless absolutely necessary. It will drive you crazy.
You need to take this class for premed, so yes. However, I wouldn't call this class enjoyable.
Most people who take the class have to take it, so unfortunately yes.
No, but its the only option for most STEM majors.

I wouldn't recommend this course to another student because it is tedious and I don't feel like I learned that much at all in terms of chemistry, only doing little tasks in the lab. The hours are terrible, the grading takes forever, and Dr. G isn't a good instructor at all. The only reason I took chem lab was to fill a requirement.
This is a great class to familiarize yourself with lab equipment and procedures. Dr G is very knowledgable and willing to help at any moment.
NO, DO NOT TAKE IT! Take it in the summer with a decent professor!!
Yes I would recommend it. It's required if you want to be pre-med.

If your major does not require this course, I would consider taking it only if you are very interested in chemistry or are thinking about doing chemistry or biology research. With that said, if you pay attention and work hard in the lab, it really isn't too bad.
Only if you need it.
no.
No- do not take this class if not required for major, workload is unnecessarily large for minimal learning.
Yes, especially if its required.
Yes, if they were interested in chemistry. I would not recommend it to someone who was looking for a laid back class and wasn't planning on pursuing something in which they needed these skills.
I would say they shouldn't take it unless required for a prospective major.

Not unless you have to take it. It provides some useful knowledge for anyone who intends to continue in biology or chemistry, but it is not in itself a particularly interesting or enjoyable class. It helps explain some of the concepts that are important in general chemistry but is not fulfilling on its own.

I wouldn't recommend this class unless you needed it for your major/pre-med. The grading is pretty subjective, the lab reports are lengthy, and 4-hour labs are generally not the best way to spend your afternoons. However, I would say that this class is better than Gen Chem Lab I.
Yes because it is required for premed.
I would recommend this course so that they get a foundational chemical knowledge that they can apply in the laboratory setting.
I would not recommend this course unless necessary.
